title: 112_hr700
content:
The "Floodplain Maps Moratorium Act" delays the mandatory purchase requirement for new flood hazard areas by 5 years. The Floodplain Maps Moratorium Act amends the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 to delay the mandatory purchase requirement for new flood hazard areas that are designated after September 30, 2007, for 5 years if certain conditions are met. The Floodplain Maps Moratorium Act amends the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 to delay the mandatory purchase requirement for new flood hazard areas for 5 years if evacuation and communication plans are developed before the effective date of the maps. The Floodplain Maps Moratorium Act delays the mandatory purchase requirement for new flood hazard areas for 5 years if evacuation and communication plans are developed. The communication plan advises occupants of potential flood risks, evacuation routes, flood insurance purchase, and consequences of not purchasing insurance. Nothing in the act affects the designation of special flood hazard areas for insurance coverage, land management criteria, notification of hazards, or eligibility for mitigation assistance. The preferred risk rate method premium is available for flood insurance coverage in specific areas and time periods. A conforming amendment is made to the National Flood Insurance Act. No refunds are authorized for flood insurance coverage purchased during periods when coverage is not required. SEC. 3. Notification to homeowners about mandatory purchase requirement. Section 201 of the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 is amended to include an annual notification requirement for residents in flood hazard areas. The notification will include information about residing in a flood hazard area, geographical boundaries, flood insurance purchase requirements, and estimated insurance costs for similar homeowners. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF ESTABLISHMENT OF FLOOD ELEVATIONS.

Section 1360 of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to require notification to Members of Congress of any revision or update of floodplain areas or flood-risk zones. The Director must inform Senators and House Members in writing of any significant actions related to these updates.

SEC. 5. REVIEW OF FLOOD MAP CHANGES BY AFFECTED COMMUNITIES. SEC. 5. REVIEW OF FLOOD MAP CHANGES BY AFFECTED COMMUNITIES: The Director must notify communities three years before flood map changes take effect, allowing them to review and propose modifications. SEC. 6. REVIEW OF FLOOD MAP METHODOLOGY: The Comptroller General of the United States will review flood insurance rate map methodology every ten years and report findings to Congress and the Director. SEC. 7. APPEALS. SEC. 7. APPEALS. Amendments to the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 require notifying local television and radio stations for flood elevation determinations. Applicable to areas without a Letter of Final Determination. The Administrator of FEMA must submit a report to Congress within 6 months outlining a plan to repay all flood insurance debts within 10 years, as required by the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968.
